It's going to sound weird, but a lot of electrical things will work just fine while they are filled with water. The wiring the electricity is supposed to flow through has a lower resistance than the water does. The only side effect, of course, is that it will still drain the battery is really fast. Simple things like flashlights will continue to work even when filled with water.

fun fact about plasma balls that few people know about:
it becomes quite frustrating to use touch screen devices such as your phone around them.
this is because the plasma effects the air outside of the glass, causing your phone to think your touching the screen when your not.
this effect is probably the same one that caused their monitor to malfunction.
a fun way to keep family off their phones when they visit your house is to keep a few plasma balls on and hidden around the areas you’d expect them to be playing on their phones, like inside the end tables in the living room by the couch. :)

3:02 More often than not they fill "neon" signs" with argon gas. Neon has a red-orange glow so the photons emitted don't have enough energy to fluoresce much at all, however in argon, the light emitted is violet so it does. The fancy neon sign colors they use are mostly from the phosphor coating in the tubes or a mixture of the original light and the phosphor light (just like how a white led excites a phosphor with blue light to yield orange and the resulting mixed light appears white).
